sen.j: 禅定寺（ぜんじょうじ）は京都府綴喜郡宇治田原町禅定寺にある曹洞宗の寺院。
sen.e: Zenjo-ji Temple is one of the temples of Soto sect, that is located in Zenjyo-ji, Ujitawara-cho, Tsuzuki County, Kyoto Prefecture.
Zenjo-ji Temple is one of the temples of the Soto sect, that is located in Zenjyo-ji, Ujitawara-cho, Tsuzuki County, Kyoto Prefecture.
Zenjo-ji Temple is one of the temples of the Soto sect, that is located in Zenjo-ji, Ujitawara-cho, Tsuzuki County, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 山号は補陀洛山、院号は観音妙智院。
sen.e: Its sango (literally, "mountain name"), which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple, is Fudarakusan, and its Ingo (name of temple's title) is Kannon Myochi In.
Its sango (literally, "mountain name"), which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple, is Fudarakusan, and its Ingo (name of temple's title) is Kannon Myochi In.
Its sango (literally, "mountain name"), which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple, is Fudarakusan, and its Ingo (name of temple's title) is Kannon Myochi In.

sen.j: 開山は平崇。
sen.e: Kaisan (a founder of temple as the first chief priest) was Heisu.
Kaisan (founder of a temple as the first chief priest) was Heisu.
Kaisan (founder of a temple as the first chief priest) was Heisu.

sen.j: 本尊は十一面観音。
sen.e: Zenjyo-ji Temple has Eleven-faced Kannon (Goddess of Mercy) enshrined as honzon (principal image of Buddha).
Zenjyo-ji Temple has an Eleven-faced Kannon (Goddess of Mercy) enshrined as the honzon (principal image of Buddha).
Zenjo-ji Temple has an Eleven-faced Kannon (Goddess of Mercy) enshrined as the honzon (principal image of Buddha).

sen.j: 宇治田原町の郊外、滋賀県境に近い位置にある。
sen.e: Zenjyo-ji Temple is located in a suburb of Ujitawara-cho, near the border of Shiga Prefecture.
Zenjyo-ji Temple is located in a suburb of Ujitawara-cho, near the border of Shiga Prefecture.
Zenjo-ji Temple is located in a suburb of Ujitawara-cho, near the border of Shiga Prefecture.

sen.j: 近世以降は曹洞宗の禅寺となっているが、元は東大寺の末寺であり、平等院や藤原摂関家ともゆかりの深い寺院で、本尊十一面観音立像をはじめ、平安時代にさかのぼる仏像群を有する。
sen.e: Although this temple has become a Zen temple (a temple belonging to the Zen sect) of Soto Sect after the early-modern times, it was originally a branch temple of Todai-ji Temple and deeply associated with Byodoin Temple and the FUJIWARA Sekkan-ke (the families which produced regents), and has a group of Buddhist statues such as Honzon standing statue of Eleven-faced Kannon dating back to Heian Period.

Although this temple has become a Zen temple (a temple belonging to the Zen sect) of the Soto Sect after the early-modern times, it was originally a branch temple of Todai-ji Temple and deeply associated with Byodoin Temple and the FUJIWARA Sekkan-ke (the families which produced regents), and has a group of Buddhist statues such as the Honzon standing statue of an Eleven-faced Kannon dating back to the Heian Period.

Although this temple has become a Zen temple (a temple belonging to the Zen sect) of the Soto Sect after the early-modern times, it was originally a branch temple of Todai-ji Temple and deeply associated with Byodoin Temple and the FUJIWARA Sekkan-ke (the families which produced regents), and has a group of Buddhist statues such as the Honzon standing statue of an Eleven-faced Kannon dating back to the Heian period.
sen.cmt: スペース削除用語統一

sen.j: 禅定寺は、宇治方面から淀川の支流田原川に沿って近江（滋賀県）の石山方面へと向かう道沿い、滋賀県境に近い山里に位置する。
sen.e: Go along a tributary of the Yodo-gawa River, the Tahara-gawa River, from Uji toward Ishiyama in Omi (Shiga Prefecture), Zenjo-ji Temple is located along the road of mountain village near the border of Shiga Prefecture.

Running along a tributary of the Yodo-gawa River and Tahara-gawa River, from Uji towards Ishiyama in Omi (Shiga Prefecture), Zenjo-ji Temple is located along the road of a mountain village near the border of Shiga Prefecture.

Running along a tributary of the Yodo-gawa River and Tahara-gawa River, from Uji towards Ishiyama in Omi (Shiga Prefecture), Zenjo-ji Temple is located along the road of a mountain village near the border of Shiga Prefecture.

sen.j: この地域は平安時代中期以前には久和利郷と呼ばれ、禅定寺の前身にあたる桑在寺（くわりじ）という寺があったという。
sen.e: This area was called Kuwari-go (village) before mid Heian period, and it is said that there used to be the former Zenjo-ji Temple, Kuwari-ji Temple.
This area was called Kuwari-go (village) before the mid Heian period, and it is said that there used to be a former Zenjo-ji Temple, Kuwari-ji Temple.
This area was called Kuwari-go (village) before the mid Heian period, and it is said that there used to be a former Zenjo-ji Temple, Kuwari-ji Temple.

sen.j: 寺に伝わる『禅定寺造営年次目録』によれば、この寺は東大寺の別当（寺を統括する最高位の僧）などを務めた僧・平崇によって創建されたものである。
sen.e: According to "The Chronological List of the Construction of Zenjo-ji Temple" that has been handed down in this temple, Zenjo-ji Temple was erected by the monk Heisu who served as Betto (the head priest and administrator of a Buddhist temple) of Todai-ji Temple.

According to "The Chronological List of the Construction of Zenjo-ji Temple" that has been handed down in this temple, Zenjo-ji Temple was erected by the monk Heisu who served as Betto (the head priest and administrator of a Buddhist temple) of Todai-ji Temple.

According to "The Chronological List of the Construction of Zenjo-ji Temple" that has been handed down in this temple, Zenjo-ji Temple was erected by the monk Heisu who served as Betto (the head priest and administrator of a Buddhist temple) of Todai-ji Temple.

sen.j: 平崇は藤原兼家（藤原道長の父、関白、太政大臣）の帰依を受けて永延元年（987年）より造営を開始。
sen.e: This temple was started to erect in 987, by accepting FUJIWARA no Kaneie's becoming believer in Buddhism,
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳分の例外対処
sen.e: Construction of the temple started in 987, by accepting FUJIWARA no Kaneie's as a believer in Buddhism,
Construction of the temple started in 987, by accepting FUJIWARA no Kaneie as a believer in Buddhism.
sen.cmt: スペルカンマをピリオドに

sen.j: 正暦2年（991年）に本堂を建て始め、完成したのは長徳元年（995年）であるという（この間、正暦元年・990年には兼家が没している）。
sen.e: Then, Hondo (main hall) was started to erect in 991, and completed in 995 (during this time, Kaneie died in 990).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳分の例外対処
sen.e: Then, construction on the Hondo (main hall) was started in 991 and completed in 995 (during this time, Kaneie died in 990).
Then, construction on the Hondo (main hall) was started in 991 and completed in 995 (during this time, Kaneie died in 990).

sen.j: それから数年後の長保3年（1001年）の日付をもつ「禅定寺領田畠流記帳」によると、禅定寺は地元の田原郷に一千町歩の杣山や田畑を有し、その他の地方にも寺領を有していた。
sen.e: According to "Records of the rice fields and vegetable fields belonging to Zenjo-ji Temple " which was written several years later in 1001, Zenjo-ji Temple had one thousand hectare of somayama (timber forest) and fields in its home town of Tahara-go as well as jiryo (temple estake) in other regions.

According to "Records of the rice fields and vegetable fields belonging to Zenjo-ji Temple " which was written several years later in 1001, Zenjo-ji Temple had 1000 hectares of somayama (timber forest) and fields in its home town of Tahara-go as well as jiryo (temple estate) in other regions.

According to "Records of the rice fields and vegetable fields belonging to Zenjo-ji Temple" which was written several years later in 1001, Zenjo-ji Temple had 1000 hectares of somayama (timber forest) and fields in its home town of Tahara-go as well as jiryo (temple estate) in other regions.

sen.j: この禅定寺領は延久元年（1071年）、平等院に寄進され、禅定寺は平等院の末寺となった（それ以前は東大寺に平崇が建てた正法院の末であった）。
sen.e: In 1071, after the rice fields and vegetable fields belonging to Zenjo-ji Temple was donated to Byodoin Temple, Zenjyo-ji Temple became a branch temple of Byodoin Temple (Until then, Zenjo-ji Temple was a branch temple of Shoboin Temple in Todai-ji Temple that was erected by Heisu.)

In 1071, after the rice fields and vegetable fields belonging to Zenjo-ji Temple were donated to Byodoin Temple, Zenjyo-ji Temple became a branch temple of Byodoin Temple (until then, Zenjo-ji Temple was a branch temple of Shoboin Temple in Todai-ji Temple that was erected by Heisu).

In 1071, after the rice fields and vegetable fields belonging to Zenjo-ji Temple were donated to Byodoin Temple, Zenjo-ji Temple became a branch temple of Byodoin Temple (until then, Zenjo-ji Temple was a branch temple of Shoboin Temple in Todai-ji Temple that was erected by Heisu).

sen.j: このように、禅定寺は平安時代を通じて藤原道長、藤原頼通（道長の子、平等院の建立者）らの貴族の帰依を受け、広大な寺領を背景に栄えた。
sen.e: In this way, Zenjyo-ji Temple flourished through Heian period by accepting nobles such as FUJIWARA no Michinaga and FUJIWARA no Yorimichi (a son of Michinaga and erector of Byodoin Temple) becoming believers in Buddhism and based on its broad ryoji,

In this way, Zenjyo-ji Temple flourished through the Heian period by accepting nobles such as FUJIWARA no Michinaga and FUJIWARA no Yorimichi (a son of Michinaga and erector of Byodoin Temple) as believers in Buddhism and based on its broad ryoji.

In this way, Zenjo-ji Temple flourished through the Heian period by accepting nobles such as FUJIWARA no Michinaga and FUJIWARA no Yorimichi (a son of Michinaga and erector of Byodoin Temple) as believers in Buddhism and based on its broad ryoji.

sen.j: 寺の運営は寄人（よりうど）と称される、寺に所属する領民によって支えられていた。
sen.e: Management of the temple was supported by ryomin (people of the domain) belonging to the temple, called Yoriudo.
Management of the temple was supported by ryomin (people of the domain) belonging to the temple, called Yoriudo.
Management of the temple was supported by ryomin (people of the domain) belonging to the temple, called Yoriudo.

sen.j: 寺に残る文書によると、中世の禅定寺は近隣との境争論をたびたび起こしており、中でも九条家領（最勝金剛院領）の曽束荘（そつかのしょう、現大津市大石曽束町）との山堺争論は中世から近世末期まで延々と争われたことで著名である。
sen.e: According to the documents remaining in the temple, Zenjyo-ji Temple in medieval period often disputed with its neighbors over village borders, especially, a dispute about the mountain border with Sotsuka-no-sho Manor (present Oishisotsuka-cho, Otsu City) of the estate of Kujo Family (Saisho kongo in ryo), was well known for disputing endlessly from medieval period to in the end of Edo period.

According to the documents remaining in the temple, Zenjyo-ji Temple in the medieval period often disputed with its neighbors over village borders, especially, a dispute about the mountain border with Sotsuka-no-sho Manor (present Oishisotsuka-cho, Otsu City) of the estate of the Kujo Family (Saisho kongo in ryo), was well known for disputing endlessly from the medieval period to the end of the Edo period.

According to the documents remaining in the temple, Zenjo-ji Temple in the medieval period often disputed with its neighbors over village borders, especially, a dispute about the mountain border with Sotsuka-no-sho Manor (present Oishisotsuka-cho, Otsu City) of the estate of the Kujo family (Saisho kongo in ryo), was well known for disputing endlessly from the medieval period to the end of the Edo period.

sen.j: 寺は戦国時代には衰微したが、近世に入り、延宝8年（1680年）に加賀・大乗寺（金沢市）の中興である月舟宗胡が入寺し、加賀藩老本多家の援助を得て再興している。
sen.e: The temple was declined in Sengoku period (period of warring states), however, after entering the early-modern times, Soko GESSHU, a restorer of Taijyo-ji Temple in Kaga (Kanazawa City) entered into the temple in 1680, and the temple was restored by support from the Honda family, the principal retainer of the Kaga Domain.

The temple declined in the Sengoku period (period of warring states), however, after entering the early-modern times, Soko GESSHU, a restorer of Taijyo-ji Temple in Kaga (Kanazawa City) entered into the temple in 1680, and the temple was restored by support from the Honda family, the principal retainer of the Kaga Domain.

The temple declined in the Sengoku period (period of warring states), however, after entering the early-modern times, Soko GESSHU, a restorer of Taijo-ji Temple in Kaga (Kanazawa City) entered into the temple in 1680, and the temple was restored by support from the Honda family, the principal retainer of the Kaga Domain.

sen.j: これ以来宗旨を曹洞宗に改めて現代に至っている。
sen.e: Since then, religious Doctrine was changed to Soto sect to this date.
Since then, the religious Doctrine was changed to the Soto sect.
Since then, the religious Doctrine was changed to the Soto sect.

sen.j: 木造十一面観音立像

sen.j: - 像高286cm。
sen.e: height: 286 cm
- Height: 286 cm
Height: 286 cm

sen.j: 量感のある体躯表現に平安時代初期様式の名残が伺えるが、表情は和風化し、衣文の彫りもおだやかで、禅定寺が創建された10世紀末頃の作と思われる。
sen.e: The trace of early Heian Period's style can be seen from well-rounded figure of statue, however facial expression becomes Japanese style, carving of clothes is gentle and it seems that this is a work around the end of 10th century, the time when Zenjyo-ji Temple was erected.

The trace of early Heian Period style can be seen from the well-rounded figure of the statue, however the facial expression is Japanese style, carving of clothes is gentle and it seems that this is a work around the end of the 10th century, the time when Zenjyo-ji Temple was erected.

The trace of early Heian period style can be seen from the well-rounded figure of the statue, however the facial expression is Japanese style, carving of clothes is gentle and it seems that this is a work around the end of the 10th century, the time when Zenjo-ji Temple was erected.

sen.j: 以下の諸仏も平安時代中期～後期の作である。

sen.j: 京阪宇治駅または近鉄新田辺駅より京阪宇治バス緑苑坂・工業団地方面行き維中前（いちゅうまえ）下車
